questions.text: A 2-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of irritability and vomiting for 2 hours. During this period, he has vomited bilious fluid three times. He has not yet passed stool. The mother has breastfed the newborn every 2 hours. He has wet two diapers during the last 2 days. He was born at term and was delivered at home. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother had no prenatal care during pregnancy. The patient currently weighs 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz) and is 50 cm (19.6 in) in length. The newborn appears restless. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.14°F), pulse is 166/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. There is no redness or warmth around the umbilical cord stump. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Bowel sounds are sparse. The abdomen is distended. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen with contrast shows dilated small bowel loops, a microcolon, and a mixture of gas and meconium located in the right lower quadrant. A nasogastric tube is placed and fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance with later follow-up would not be appropriate management for this infant who has several concerning symptoms including vomiting and inability to pass stool. Delayed treatment in an infant with symptoms of bowel obstruction may lead to dehydration, intestinal perforation, or meconium peritonitis. In this newborn, urgent management is warranted to prevent such complications.

B) CORRECT:

Gastrografin enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic for meconium ileus. A gastrografin enema will allow visualization of the rectum and bowel to rule out other anatomical causes for bowel obstruction (e.g., intestinal atresia or volvulus) and, in the case of meconium ileus, can reveal the Neuhauser sign, microcolon, or meconium pellets. The contrast agent can also induce a laxative effect as the increase of osmolarity within the lumen of the bowel results in the breakdown and passage of the meconium obstruction.

More than 90% of patients with meconium ileus will have cystic fibrosis (CF). For unknown reasons, newborn screens for CF in patients with meconium ileus are often initially negative and require additional testing. Infants with meconium ileus should undergo diagnostic testing for CF through a sweat test or, if sufficient amounts of sweat cannot be obtained, through genotyping.

C) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy should be considered in patients presenting with symptoms of obstruction when there is concern for bowel perforation, peritonitis, or volvulus and associated bowel ischemia. This newborn does not have any free air on x-ray nor contrast leak that would suggest bowel perforation. He is hemodynamically stable and afebrile and his abdomen is distended, but there is no guarding or abdominal rigidity, which would suggest peritonitis, although these findings are unreliable in a newborn. This newborn should undergo nonsurgical management. Surgery would be considered only when meconium ileus is complicated or if nonsurgical treatment fails.

D) INCORRECT:

A rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard confirmatory test for Hirschsprung's disease. Newborns with Hirschsprung's disease also present with symptoms of bowel obstruction and inability to pass stool, but rectal examination often reveals a tight anal sphincter and explosive discharge of stool and gas. This patient had a normal rectal exam with x-ray showing evidence of obstruction in the terminal ileum instead of the colon and no signs of reduced caliber of the rectum, making Hirschsprung's disease an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy can be used to visualize the rectum and colon in patients presenting with symptoms of bowel obstruction. Colonoscopy is an invasive procedure that requires sedating the newborn; less invasive diagnostic modalities should be considered first.

F) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen with contrast can be used to assess the level and severity of intestinal blockage in patients in whom bowel obstruction is suspected, especially in adults. In a newborn presenting with symptoms of bowel obstruction, anatomic causes for obstruction (e.g., duodenal stenosis, ileal atresia) need to be investigated via imaging. However, in children, and especially in a 2-day-old newborn, a CT scan should be avoided whenever possible to minimize radiation exposure and associated long-term complications.
questions.hint: This newborn presents with bilious vomiting, a distended abdomen, and sparse bowel sounds, all of which are consistent with bowel obstruction. The findings of dilated small bowel loops on abdominal x-ray and a microcolon indicate meconium ileus as the cause for obstruction and explains why he has not yet passed stool.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a follow-up examination. Since early childhood, he has had recurrent respiratory infections that cause him to miss several weeks of school each year. Last month, he received treatment for his seventh episode of sinusitis this year. He has always had bulky, foul-smelling, oily stools that are now increasing in frequency. His parents are concerned that he is too thin and not gaining weight appropriately. He has a good appetite and eats a variety of foods. He is a native of India and immigrated to the United States 10 years ago. He is in the 10th percentile for height and the 5th percentile for weight. Examination of the nasal cavity shows multiple nasal polyps. The lung fields are clear upon auscultation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin hypersensitivity is a characteristic feature of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), which may result in nasal polyposis due to chronic rhinitis. However, patients with AERD also have a history of asthma, and AERD does not result in steatorrhea or a failure to thrive.

B) CORRECT:

Over 98% of men with cystic fibrosis have a congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens, which results in azoospermia and infertility.

For this patient, the next best step is to confirm that diagnosis using a sweat chloride test. A sweat chloride concentration ≥ 60 mmol/L confirms the diagnosis. If the value is between 30 and 60 mmol/L, a CFTR gene analysis needs to be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Situs inversus along with recurrent sinopulmonary infections is characteristic of Kartagener syndrome. Half of patients with Kartagener syndrome will have situs inversus. Nasal polyposis (due to recurrent URTI) and failure to thrive may also be present. However, the presence of steatorrhea suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, which is not associated with an increased risk of situs inversus.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoplastic tonsils and adenoids are seen in certain primary immunodeficiency syndromes such as X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) and severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Both XLA and SCID have similar clinical manifestations, including recurrent infections, chronic diarrhea, and a failure to thrive. However, both of these conditions typically manifest during early childhood. Also, patients with SCID would not be expected to survive to the age of 14 without treatment. The presence of steatorrhea also suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Selective IgA deficiency can result in recurrent sinopulmonary infections, diarrhea (due to gastrointestinal infections), and a failure to thrive. However, the oily, foul-smelling stools are more indicative of steatorrhea than diarrhea from an infection. Steatorrhea is not typically associated with selective IgA deficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

A positive methacholine challenge test can suggest bronchial asthma. The typical presentation of asthma is episodic wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath, often with an environmental trigger (e.g., cigarette smoke, dust mites). Although this patient has respiratory problems, there is no history of episodic wheezing and chest tightness.

G) INCORRECT:

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are thought to mediate the autoimmune phenomena that lead to celiac disease (CD). CD can result in failure to thrive and steatorrhea beginning in early childhood. About 1–2% of patients with CD have an associated IgA deficiency, which can manifest as recurrent sinopulmonary infections. However, recurrent sinusitis is not a typical feature of CD, and children with this condition usually have anorexia.
questions.hint: This patient has recurrent upper respiratory infections (and subsequent nasal polyposis) and signs of pancreatic insufficiency (steatorrhea and malabsorption) with resulting failure to thrive, both of which suggest cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because she is severely underweight. She is easily fatigued and has difficulty keeping up with other children at her daycare. She has a good appetite and eats 3 full meals a day. She has 4 to 5 bowel movements daily with bulky, foul-smelling stools that float. She has had recurrent episodes of sinusitis since infancy. Her parents report that she recently started to snore during her sleep. She is at the 15th percentile for height and 3rd percentile for weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. A few scattered expiratory crackles are heard in the thorax. There is abdominal distention. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's failure to thrive?

choices.text: Mucosal damage from excessive gastric acid
T. whippelii infiltration of intestinal villi

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, which results from hyperviscous pancreatic secretions, occurs in over half of patients with CF and manifests with failure to thrive due to malabsorption. Additionally, patients often have abdominal distention (from bacterial fermentation of undigested food), steatorrhea, and deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). Diagnosis of CF is typically established by neonatal screening, as all newborns in the US are screened for this condition.

In this patient, CF can be confirmed with sweat chloride testing (gold standard) or DNA testing. A decreased stool chymotrypsin and pancreatic elastase are helpful in the diagnosis of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Mucosal damage from excessive gastric acid occurs in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which may manifest with steatorrhea and weight loss (due to inactivation of pancreatic enzymes from excess acid). However, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is usually associated with abdominal pain and recurrent, therapy-resistant peptic ulcer disease. In addition, the age of onset for Zollinger-Ellison is typically 30–50 years, and this diagnosis would not explain the recurrent upper respiratory infections seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Small intestine bacterial overgrowth may manifest with diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and malabsorption. However, it is most commonly caused by complications of abdominal surgery (such as blind loop syndrome) and gastrointestinal motility disorders. Also, small intestine bacterial overgrowth would not explain this patient's recurrent upper respiratory infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired intestinal amino acid transport is seen in Hartnup disease. While niacin deficiency (vitamin B3 deficiency) from reduced tryptophan can cause diarrhea (from pellagra), these symptoms are usually associated with dermatitis, as well as neurologic symptoms (ataxia, confusion, dementia). Also, Hartnup disease would not explain the recurrent upper episodes of sinusitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Intestinal inflammatory reaction to gluten is seen in celiac disease. Celiac disease may manifest with malabsorption symptoms, such as steatorrhea, anemia, and failure to thrive, but it would not explain this patient's recurrent upper respiratory symptoms. Also, celiac disease often occurs in association with extraintestinal features including dermatological symptoms (e.g., dermatitis herpetiformis, vitiligo) and endocrine symptoms (e.g., autoimmune thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus).

F) INCORRECT:

Tropheryma whipplei infiltration of intestinal villi causes Whipple disease, which may manifest with malabsorption and steatorrhea. However, Whipple disease is rare and mainly affects men aged 48–54 years. In addition, most cases of Whipple disease are associated with enteropathic arthritis (classically preceding gastrointestinal symptoms) and may also be associated with sacroiliitis, fever, or polyserositis. Furthermore, recurrent episodes of sinusitis are suggestive of another diagnosis.
questions.hint: Steatorrhea, abdominal distention, failure to thrive, and signs of anemia (fatigue, pale conjunctivae) indicate malabsorption. Together with recurrent episodes of upper respiratory infections and recent onset of snoring (which likely indicates nasal polyposis), this suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF).

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a productive cough for the past 5 days. He has a history of recurrent lower respiratory tract infections and sinusitis treated with oral antibiotics. He frequently has loose stools that do not flush easily. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and the neonatal period was complicated by meconium ileus. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 15th percentile for height and at the 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 38/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Examination shows bilateral nasal polyps. There are scattered inspiratory crackles heard in the thorax. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Recurrent pulmonary infections and chronic bronchitis in CF lead to obstructive lung disease with increased air trapping and lung hyperinflation, resulting in increased, not decreased, residual volumes.

B) CORRECT:

Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency arising from hyperviscous secretions in CF leads to malabsorption, steatorrhea, and deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K). Vitamin K deficiency causes coagulopathy and an elevated prothrombin time.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with CF may lose an excess of chloride in their sweat (due to defective chloride channels), resulting in chloride-dependent metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA) are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, or formerly Wegener granulomatosis). GPA may cause recurrent sinusitis and persistent, pneumonia-like symptoms (cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis, wheezing). However, GPA is not associated with steatorrhea or meconium ileus and is rare in childhood (peak incidence: 65–74 years).

E) INCORRECT:

Glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) autoantibodies are present in type I diabetes mellitus (T1DM). CF may cause diabetes later in life (CF-related diabetes) due to destruction of pancreatic islet cells from chronic pancreatic duct obstruction. CF is not, however, associated with T1DM or the presence of GAD autoantibodies.

F) INCORRECT:

Aganglionic rectum is seen in Hirschsprung disease, which may be associated with Down syndrome. The patient's recurrent respiratory infections, steatorrhea, and history of meconium ileus in childhood is suggestive of CF, which has no association with Hirschsprung disease.
questions.hint: Pancreatic insufficiency in cystic fibrosis (CF) leads to malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of an increasing productive cough with a moderate amount of white phlegm for the past week. He has been treated for pneumonia with antibiotic therapy four times over the past year. A chest x-ray performed 3 months ago showed no anatomical abnormalities. He has had multiple episodes of foul-smelling, bulky, greasy stools. He is at the 3rd percentile for height and at the 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 44/min. A few inspiratory crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best initial test to determine the underlying etiology of this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a CT scan of the chest may provide information about changes to lung structures, it would not be diagnostic for determining the underlying illness in this boy. Additionally, CT scans emit high doses of radiation and should be avoided, if possible, in a 2-year-old child.

B) INCORRECT:

Although an x-ray of the chest may be helpful in visualizing an infiltrate, it would not be specific enough to determine the underlying etiology of the patient's recurrent infections. Additionally, the patient's prior chest x-ray did not reveal any anatomical abnormalities that could potentially be the cause of his recurrent sinopulmonary infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) may be helpful in evaluating for restrictive or obstructive lung disease. However, PFTs would not be specific enough to determine the underlying etiology of this boy's illness. Also, PFTs may be difficult to obtain in children less than 6 years of age and therefore are not completely reliable.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum immunoglobulin levels may be low in immunodeficiency states like selective IgA deficiency (showing low IgA and normal IgG and IgM) or common variable immunodeficiency (showing low levels of IgA, IgG, and IgM). While both conditions can manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea, they are not commonly associated with steatorrhea and failure to thrive.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has typical clinical manifestations of cystic fibrosis (CF; chronic sinopulmonary disease, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency). The sweat chloride test, or quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis, is the gold standard test for CF. Defective chloride channels lead to elevated chloride in sweat gland secretions; levels > 60 mmol/L on two or more occasions are diagnostic for this condition.

F) INCORRECT:

Stool analysis, particularly measurements of stool elastase or chymotrypsin, would be useful for diagnosing exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. However, this would not confirm the patient's underlying cause of pancreatic insufficiency.

G) INCORRECT:

DNA phenotyping may be performed for this patient's condition if there is high clinical suspicion and the best initial test is negative, or performed after best initial testing is positive to help guide treatment decisions. However, it would not be the best initial test (and is not used for screening), as it is expensive and results are not obtained quickly.
questions.hint: The underlying illness can manifest with meconium ileus in the neonatal period.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Since infancy, he has frequently had large-volume stools that are loose and greasy. He was treated for otitis media twice in the past year. He has a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections since birth. He is at the 5th percentile for height and 3rd percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows softening of the occipital and parietal bones. Scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

α1-antitrypsin deficiency is associated with panlobular emphysema (resulting in dyspnea and expiratory wheezing, possibly associated with upper respiratory infections) and cirrhosis (before the age of 50), but not with steatorrhea, failure to thrive, or vitamin D deficiency with craniotabes, which suggest exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Gliadin autoantibodies are characteristic of celiac disease (CD). CD may manifest with malabsorption, steatorrhea, failure to thrive, and vitamin D deficiency. Also, 3% of patients with CD have selective IgA deficiency, which is often asymptomatic but may predispose to recurrent sinusitis or respiratory infections. However, these infections are usually mild. This patient presents with expiratory wheezing and rhonchi on auscultation in the absence of fever or cough, which makes a noninfectious underlying cause of his pulmonary disease more likely.

C) CORRECT:

CFTR gene mutations are the underlying cause of cystic fibrosis (CF), which can manifest with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (characterized by steatorrhea, failure to thrive, and vitamin D deficiency with craniotabes) and recurrent infections. The mutated CFTR gene encodes defective chloride channels in the cell membrane of exocrine glands, leading to hyperviscosity of secretions, blockage of exocrine glands, and eventual chronic inflammation with permanent organ damage. The most common mutation is ΔF508.

CF is usually discovered during neonatal screening. The sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosis, but genetic testing can also be used. If either test is inconclusive, the nasal potential difference test is performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Low to absent T cells are a characteristic laboratory finding in severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Although SCID can manifest with recurrent respiratory infections (usually severe), failure to thrive, and loose stools (from infective diarrheal illness), it is not associated with steatorrhea or vitamin D deficiency with craniotabes, which suggest exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired ciliary function is the hallmark of Kartagener syndrome. While Kartagener syndrome can cause recurrent respiratory tract infections, it is not associated with steatorrhea, failure to thrive, or vitamin D deficiency with craniotabes, which instead suggest exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Also, Kartagener syndrome is associated with situs inversus.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is strongly associated with meconium ileus in neonates.

questions.text: Two days after delivery, a 2450-g (5-lb 6-oz) male newborn has three episodes of green vomitus. He has passed urine twice daily but has not yet passed stool. He was born at 34 weeks' gestation. He appears irritable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 161/min, respirations are 56/min, and blood pressure is 62/44 mm Hg. Examination shows a distended abdomen; there is diffuse tenderness to palpation over the abdomen. Bowel sounds are decreased. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen shows dilated bowel loops. Contrast enema demonstrates inspissated meconium plugs in the distal ileum and microcolon. This patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meconium ileus is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF), which may lead to diabetes later in life (CF-related diabetes) caused by the destruction of pancreatic islet cells as a result of chronic pancreatic duct obstruction. CF is not, however, associated with type I diabetes mellitus.

B) CORRECT:

Meconium ileus is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). If the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) protein is defective, viscous mucus obstructs the formation of the vas deferens during the development of the genital tract. This obstruction results in the congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens in ∼ 98% of male individuals with CF, leading to infertility. Additionally, individuals with CF may have a decreased sperm count, which supports the theory that CFTR might also play a direct role in sperm maturation and development. However, spermatogenesis may be intact and individuals with CF can still have children via sperm retrieval and in vitro fertilization.

C) INCORRECT:

Delayed passage of meconium can be seen in Hirschsprung disease, which is associated with Down syndrome (and, consequently, Alzheimer disease). Children with Hirschsprung disease demonstrate failure to pass meconium in the first 24–48 hours. However, the obstruction is most commonly located in the rectal or sigmoid colon (the location of aganglionic colon) and not in the distal ileum (from inspissated meconium causing meconium ileus).

D) INCORRECT:

Meconium ileus is associated with cystic fibrosis (CF). While both CF and asthma may cause obstructive lung disease, CF causes chronic respiratory infections and bronchiectasis and is not associated with asthma (which is characterized by bronchial hyperresponsiveness and reversible airway obstruction).

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation of meconium ileus is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). While CF can cause fat-soluble vitamin deficiency from exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, there is no association with water-soluble vitamin deficiencies like thiamine deficiency.
questions.hint: A distended abdomen and bilious vomiting in a newborn should raise suspicion for a bowel obstruction. Imaging studies confirm small bowel obstruction with meconium plugs in the distal ileum and microcolon. These findings indicate meconium ileus.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of increasing swelling of his legs and generalized fatigue for 1 month. During this period he has also had a productive cough and shortness of breath. He has been unable to carry out his daily activities. He has a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections and chronic nasal congestion since childhood. He has a 3-month history of foul-smelling and greasy stools. He is at the 4th percentile for height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 104/64 mm Hg. Examination shows clubbing of his fingers and scoliosis. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Jugular venous distention is present. Inspiratory crackles are heard in the thorax. Cardiac examination shows a loud S2. The abdomen is mildly distended and the liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis in children/adolescents can cause cardiac failure and is most commonly caused by a viral infection (e.g., coxsackie virus, adenovirus, parvovirus B19, EBV, CMV). So a history of a recent respiratory/gastrointestinal illness which precedes the onset of cardiac complaints is commonly present. However, this child has a history of chronic respiratory complaints and additional clinical features (steatorrhea, failure to thrive) that cannot be explained by myocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this child has idiopathic scoliosis (an etiological factor for the development of extrinsic restrictive lung disease) and cor pulmonale (a complication of chronic restrictive lung disease), extrinsic restrictive lung disease would not explain this patient's steatorrhea or recurrent infections. Moreover, the cough in restrictive lung diseases is characteristically dry.

C) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) can cause dependent edema and failure to thrive (due to proteinuria). However, cor pulmonale, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, chronic respiratory tract disease, and clubbing are not seen in nephrotic syndrome. In addition, the onset of MCD is usually acute, often following a mild respiratory tract infection, and patients typically also have periorbital edema and frothy urine.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the most common inherited heart disease, may either be asymptomatic or present with features of left heart failure (angina pectoris, exertional dyspnea/palpitations, rales), rather than right heart failure (pedal edema, hepatomegaly, elevated jugular venous distention). HCM is not a cause of steatorrhea and failure to thrive, suggesting an alternative diagnosis in this child.

E) INCORRECT:

Severe protein malnutrition can result in dependent edema, failure to thrive, recurrent infections, and rarely, heart failure. However, pure protein malnutrition does not cause steatorrhea or clubbing. A child with protein malnutrition severe enough to cause heart failure would also have other significant clinical features, such as bradycardia (rather than tachycardia), dry, brittle hair and nails, dry skin, and redundant skin folds.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency can also present with respiratory complaints (chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and fatigue due to emphysema), failure to thrive, and cor pulmonale. However, features of liver disease (hepatitis or cirrhosis) would also be expected. Also, α1-antitrypsin deficiency does not cause steatorrhea.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with Goodpasture syndrome can present with respiratory complaints, such as dyspnea and chronic cough (due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage), and edema (due to the proteinuria of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). However, pancreatic involvement (as evidenced by steatorrhea) and systemic symptoms (fatigue and failure to thrive) are characteristically absent in patients with Goodpasture syndrome.

H) CORRECT:

Patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) present with multiorgan disease (especially of the lungs and the pancreas) due to hyperviscosity of exocrine secretions. This patient has a history of chronic respiratory tract disease (productive cough, recurrent respiratory tract infections, and chronic nasal congestion), which has caused cor pulmonale to develop and result in right heart failure (pedal edema, dyspnea, elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and a loud S2). His fatty stools are a sign of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Moreover, failure to thrive (< 5th percentile for height- and weight-for-age), clubbing, and scoliosis are typical in CF, making it the most likely diagnosis.

Although CF is mostly diagnosed within the first 2 weeks of life (either on routine screening/evaluation of a neonate with meconium ileus) or within the first 2 years of life (in children with recurrent respiratory tract infections and failure to thrive), some patients with CF may be missed on routine screening and present in adolescence/early adulthood. The clinical diagnosis of CF should be confirmed by performing the sweat chloride test, abnormal nasal potential difference test, or gene studies for CFTR gene mutation.
questions.hint: This condition also commonly results in nephrolithiasis and cholelithiasis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a high fever, progressive shortness of breath, and a cough productive of moderate amounts of yellow sputum for the past 2 days. He had meconium ileus as a newborn and was subsequently diagnosed with cystic fibrosis during routine neonatal screening. Since then, he has had recurrent respiratory infections that have required hospitalization. Current medications include albuterol, pancreatic enzymes, and vitamin A and vitamin D3 supplements. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 44/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows labored breathing and subcostal retractions. There is dullness to percussion of the right upper lung; breath sounds are decreased. An x-ray of the chest shows consolidation in the right upper lobe of the lung; there is increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the upper lung fields. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the influenza A virus can cause pneumonia in patients with CF, a pulmonary consolidation suggests bacterial rather than viral pneumonia. Patients with influenza are susceptible to superinfection with the pathogen that is most commonly implicated in pulmonary infections in children with CF, which may cause them to develop secondary bacterial pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

Although Burkholderia cepacia complex can also cause pulmonary infections in patients with CF, other pathogens are much more common. B. cepacia complex can lead to cepacia syndrome in patients with CF.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of lobar pneumonia in healthy individuals. However, S. pneumoniae is a rather rare causative pathogen in patients with CF; a different pathogen is more commonly implicated.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with CF, chronic Aspergillus fumigatus infection can lead to allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), which manifests with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. However, in ABPA, the sputum typically shows brownish mucus plugs, and auscultation of the lungs typically discloses wheezing. A different pathogen is more likely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae is the most common cause of pneumonia in neonates. In children with CF, a different pathogen is much more likely.

F) CORRECT:

In infants and children with CF, Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of pulmonary infections. This patient is at risk of infections with multiresistant organisms (e.g., MRSA) because he has had recurrent respiratory infections with multiple hospitalizations. Vancomycin should therefore be included in the empiric treatment regimen of this patient’s infection. In adults with CF, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of recurrent pulmonary infections, and empiric antibiotic therapy should cover this pathogen.

G) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is a common cause of pulmonary infections in children with CF. Most children are vaccinated against H. influenzae type B, and pneumonia is usually caused by the nontypeable strains of Haemophilus. However, a different pathogen is much more commonly implicated than H. influenzae.

H) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of recurrent pulmonary infections in adults with CF. Although P. aeruginosa can also cause pulmonary infections in children, a different pathogen is more commonly implicated.
questions.hint: This patient's history (e.g., fever, dyspnea, and productive cough) and examination findings (e.g., hypoxia, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion) in combination with a consolidation of the right upper lobe in his chest x-ray are consistent with pneumonia. The most likely causative pathogen is the most common cause of pulmonary infections in infants and children with cystic fibrosis (CF).

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Her mother has noticed that the child has had multiple falls over the past 4 months while walking, especially in the evening. Her current medications include pancreatic enzyme supplements, an albuterol inhaler, and acetylcysteine. She is at the 10th percentile for height and the 5th percentile for weight. Examination shows dry skin and cone-shaped elevated papules on the trunk and extremities. There is an irregularly shaped foamy gray patch on the left conjunctiva. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency (vitamin B3 deficiency) leads to a condition called pellagra. Dermatitis in these patients usually manifests as a symmetric rash with hyperpigmented skin lesions in the sun-exposed areas of skin, rather than the elevated papules seen on this child's trunk.

Foods rich in niacin include meat, liver, cereals, seeds, and legumes.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

B) INCORRECT:

The classic triad of zinc deficiency is acral or periorificial dermatitis (dry, erythematous dry patches in an acral distribution or surrounding body orifices), alopecia, and diarrhea. This patient's skin lesions are morphologically inconsistent with the dermatitis seen in zinc deficiency. Also, her lesions are located on the trunk and extremities, rather than the palms, soles, and nail beds, or periorally. In addition, she does not have any of the known risk factors for zinc deficiency.

Foods rich in zinc include shellfish, fish, red meat, whole grains, and nuts.

C) CORRECT:

This patient with cystic fibrosis (CF) has classic signs of vitamin A deficiency, i.e., night blindness, xerophthalmia (manifested as Bitot spots), and skin manifestations (xeroderma and follicular hyperkeratosis). Although patients with fat malabsorption disorders such as CF, celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, pancreatic insufficiency, and cholestasis are particularly vulnerable to developing vitamin A deficiency, this can be prevented with fat-soluble vitamin supplementation.

Food sources of vitamin A include liver, fish, carrots, and eggs.

D) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency leads to cheilitis, glossitis, stomatitis, normocytic normochromic anemia, seborrheic dermatitis, and a sore throat. Although riboflavin deficiency can also cause eye involvement (corneal vascularization), it does not lead to impaired vision or gray conjunctival lesions. This child does not have symptoms or risk factors for riboflavin deficiency.

Foods rich in riboflavin include meat, fish, eggs, milk, green vegetables, and yeast.

E) INCORRECT:

Lutein is a macula-protective supplement that may benefit patients with macular degeneration. Although juvenile macular degeneration could cause poor night vision in a child, this condition is extremely rare. Also, a lutein deficiency is inconsistent with the rest of this child's symptoms.
questions.hint: This treatment would also be prescribed as a part of the treatment of severe measles.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of fever, congestion, and malaise for the past 2 days. He reports a sensation of pressure over his nose and cheeks. Over the past year, he has had an intermittent cough productive of green sputum and lately has noticed some streaks of blood in the sputum. He has had over 10 episodes of sinusitis, all of which were successfully treated with antibiotics. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient's vaccinations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over both cheeks. Crackles and rhonchi are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows an absence of heart sounds along the left lower chest. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defective IL-2R gamma chain is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), a severe and rare genetic condition that results in recurrent bacterial infections and failure to thrive. Without treatment, patients with SCID typically die within a year of birth. This patient's age and dextrocardia are not consistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

An absence of B lymphocytes is characteristic of Bruton agammaglobulinemia (x-linked agammaglobulinemia). Patients with this disorder are prone to recurrent bacterial infections from a young age. Dextrocardia is not associated with this disorder and makes a different finding more likely.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

C) INCORRECT:

An increased FEV1 would be expected in individuals who are physically active (e.g., athletes). In contrast, patients with bronchiectasis typically have a decreased FEV1, indicating an obstructive pulmonary disease. With the progression of the disease, a mixed functional pattern or a restrictive pattern can be found on spirometry, reflecting the progressive destruction of the pulmonary parenchyma.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated chloride levels on a sweat test are diagnostic of cystic fibrosis (CF), which can make patients prone to chronic infections of the sinopulmonary tract. However, dextrocardia is not associated with CF, making a different finding more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Kartagener syndrome, also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia, is an autosomal recessive disorder that causes dynein arm defects, which lead to cilia dysfunction. The resulting inability to properly clear mucus in the sinopulmonary tract leads to recurrent infections, including sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia, as seen in this patient. Situs inversus (including dextrocardia) may also occur as a result of improperly functioning cilia during embryonic development. Infertility is also associated with Kartagener syndrome: in women due to ciliary defects in the fallopian tubes, and in men due to immotile sperm.

F) INCORRECT:

Low levels of all immunoglobulins are seen in common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), which is associated with recurrent pyogenic respiratory infections. However, CVID rarely becomes symptomatic before 20 years of age and is not associated with dextrocardia.

G) INCORRECT:

Genetic microdeletion at chromosome 22 results in DiGeorge syndrome, a disorder characterized by congenital heart disease, hypoplastic thymus, and T-cell deficiency. While T-cell deficiency may result in recurrent sinopulmonary infections, dextrocardia is not one of the cardiac abnormalities associated with DiGeorge syndrome. Moreover, this patient does not have any other characteristic features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as dysmorphic facial features, cleft palate, or hypocalcemia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent sinusitis, symptoms of bronchiectasis, and presumably situs inversus (absence of heart sounds on the left side), all of which are highly suggestive of Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of frequent respiratory tract infections and chronic diarrhea. His stools are bulky and greasy, and he has around 8 bowel movements daily. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Chest examination shows intercostal retractions along with diffuse wheezing and expiratory rhonchi. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?

choices.text: Altered configuration of a protease inhibitor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There are several hereditary conditions (e.g., Huntington disease, myotonic dystrophies, Fragile X syndrome, Friedreich ataxia) that result from increased frequency of trinucleotide repeats. Individuals with Fragile X and Friedreich ataxia may also present with failure to thrive, which is seen here. Recurrent sinopulmonary infections and chronic diarrhea/steatorrhea are atypical findings in trinucleotide repeat disorders.

B) INCORRECT:

Kartagener syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that causes ciliary dyskinesia. Defective ciliary action results in a triad of recurrent sinopulmonary/ear infections, situs inversus, and infertility. Although this patient has recurrent pulmonary infections, his chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea are inconsistent with Kartagener syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

A deletion of three DNA base pairs that code for phenylalanine in the CFTR gene at the amino acid position 508 (deltaF508) is the most common cause of cystic fibrosis and results in a misfolded protein and subsequent cell membrane chloride channel dysfunction. The misfolded protein is retained in the rough endoplasmic reticulum and, therefore, unable to reach the cell membrane, resulting in decreased Cl- and H2O secretion. Increased intracellular Cl- facilitates reabsorption of Na+ and H2O from the extracellular space. This causes abnormally thick secretions, predisposing patients to recurrent sinopulmonary infections, chronic GI upset, and failure to thrive, all of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is caused by a mutation in the protease inhibitor, α1-antitrypsin. This mutation results in increased activity of elastase, causing destruction of pulmonary acini and subsequent panacinar emphysema. α1-antitrypsin also accumulates within hepatocytes, ultimately leading to cirrhosis. Patients with this condition present with both respiratory and GI symptoms. However, affected individuals also have symptoms that are classically associated with emphysema and liver disease (e.g., dyspnea, jaundice), and would not typically have chronic diarrhea/steatorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by either a frameshift mutation (most common) or a nonsense mutation of the dystrophin gene. These mutations result in an absent or a truncated dystrophin protein, leading to progressive myofibril damage, proximal muscle weakness, and cardiomyopathy. This patient's presentation (chronic diarrhea, recurrent pulmonary infections, and failure to thrive) is inconsistent with DMD.
questions.hint: Recurrent respiratory infections, fat malabsorption, and failure to thrive are concerning for cystic fibrosis. This condition causes abnormal, hyperviscous secretions of exocrine glands.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever and worsening cough for the past 4 days. She has had several episodes of otitis media, sinusitis, and an intermittent cough productive of green sputum for the past 2 years. She has also noticed some streaks of blood in the sputum lately. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Auscultation of the chest reveals crackles and rhonchi bilaterally. Heart sounds cannot be heard along the left lower chest. A CT scan of the chest reveals bronchiectasis and dextrocardia. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Kartagener syndrome causes dynein arm defects that lead to cilia dysfunction. The resulting inability to properly clear mucus in the sinopulmonary tract leads to recurrent sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia. Dysfunction of cilia during embryonic development may result in situs inversus (including dextrocardia). Kartagener syndrome can cause infertility in women due to ciliary defects in the fallopian tubes, which slows the transport of the ovum into the uterine cavity. Similarly, infertility also occurs in men due to immotile sperm.

B) INCORRECT:

NADPH oxidase deficiency is the cause of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). Although respiratory tract infections are characteristic of CGD, other common clinical features such as chronic lymphadenopathy, and skin, gastrointestinal, and urinary tract infections are not present in this patient. In addition, dextrocardia is not associated with CGD.

C) INCORRECT:

Low levels of all immunoglobulins are seen in common variable immunodeficiency (CVID). CVID is associated with recurrent pyogenic respiratory infections but is not associated with dextrocardia.

D) INCORRECT:

A defective IL-2R gamma chain is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), a severe and rare genetic condition that results in recurrent bacterial infections and failure to thrive. Without treatment, patients with SCID typically die within a year of birth. This patient's age and dextrocardia are not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased sweat chloride levels is diagnostic of cystic fibrosis (CF). While patients with CF are prone to chronic infections of the sinopulmonary tract, dextrocardia is not associated with CF. In addition, this patient has no evidence of other classic features of CF such as malabsorption and foul smelling steatorrhea (fatty stools).
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent sinusitis, otitis media, bronchiectasis, and dextrocardia. These features indicate Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: A healthy 33-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 15 weeks' gestation comes to the genetic counselor for a follow-up visit. Her uncle had recurrent pulmonary infections, chronic diarrhea, and infertility, and died at the age of 28 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. The results of a genetic analysis show a deletion of Phe508 on chromosome 7. This patient's fetus is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Duodenal atresia is a congenital malformation that manifests with delayed meconium passage, bilious vomiting, and the classic double bubble sign on x-ray. Duodenal atresia is associated with Down syndrome, not cystic fibrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital megacolon (Hirschsprung disease) is caused by a failure of the neural crest cells to migrate, which leads to aganglionic colon segments and failure to pass meconium. Congenital megacolon is associated with Down syndrome, not cystic fibrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac defects are associated with a number of syndromes, including fetal alcohol syndrome, trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and trisomy 21. However, cystic fibrosis is not associated with cardiac defects.

D) CORRECT:

Meconium ileus is one of the first manifestations of cystic fibrosis seen in newborns, due to defective ATP-gated chloride channels. In response to impaired chloride secretion into the gastrointestinal (GI) lumen, sodium and water secretion in the GI tract is decreased, resulting in hyperviscous mucous in the lumen and increasing the risk of ileus. This pathophysiology is also responsible for the increased chloride concentration of the skin, which can be measured via the pilocarpine-induced sweat test.

E) INCORRECT:

Neural tube defects describe several conditions characterized by incomplete neural tube closure (e.g., spina bifida, meningomyelocele, anencephaly). The most common cause is folate deficiency during pregnancy. Neural tube defects are not associated with cystic fibrosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for pyloric stenosis include positive family history, being male, smoking during pregnancy, macrolide exposure, premature birth, and bottle feeding. Pyloric stenosis is not caused by a point mutation and is not associated with cystic fibrosis.
questions.hint: A ΔF508 mutation (deletion of phenylalanine at position 508) of the CFTR gene is the most common etiology of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of fever and productive cough. He has had similar episodes sporadically in the past with frequent episodes of thick, discolored nasal discharge. Physical examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi. An x-ray of the chest is shown. The most likely cause of recurrent infections in this patient is a dysfunction of which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alveolar macrophages are the innate defense against pathogens in the pulmonary acini. Macrophage dysfunction, such as a failure of lysosome trafficking in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, leads to recurrent pyogenic infections of the respiratory tract, mucous membranes, and skin. However, macrophage function does not rely on dynein activity and is therefore not affected by Kartagener syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Ciliated columnar epithelial cells line the upper and lower respiratory tracts and sinuses. Cilia, which are moved by dynein motor proteins, perform the vital function of mucociliary clearance, removing pathogens and clearing the airways. In Kartagener syndrome, an inherited dynein dysfunction paralyzes the cilia, leading to the blockage of the upper and lower respiratory airways and infertility.

C) INCORRECT:

Type I pneumocytes comprise > 95% of the alveolar surface and are necessary for optimal gas exchange. Their numbers are diminished in emphysema (e.g., in cystic fibrosis, alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency). Type 1 pneumocyte function does not rely on dynein activity and is therefore not affected by Kartagener syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Club cells are nonciliated cuboidal cells that line the distal terminal bronchioles and respiratory bronchioles. These cells secrete glycosaminoglycans and lysozymes, thereby degrading toxins to maintain the integrity of the respiratory epithelium. Club cell function does not rely on dynein activity and is therefore not affected by Kartagener syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Type II pneumocytes are cuboidal cells that secrete surfactant and act as a reserve for type I and II pneumocytes following lung injury. Dysfunction of these cells decreases both surfactant production and lung compliance, leading to lung collapse. Type II pneumocyte function does not rely on dynein activity and is therefore not affected by Kartagener syndrome.
questions.hint: A patient presenting with situs inversus (dextrocardia with a left-sided liver on x-ray) and signs of chronic sinusitis (a history of productive cough and frequent episodes of thick, discolored nasal discharge) most likely has Kartagener syndrome due to an inherited dynein dysfunction.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of worsening confusion, high-grade fever, and a productive cough. She has had recurrent respiratory infections and bulky, foul-smelling, oily stools since infancy. She is at the 14th percentile for height and 8th percentile for weight. Despite appropriate care, the patient dies 2 days after admission. Autopsy of the lungs shows bronchial mucus plugging and bronchiectasis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Deletion of phenylalanine codon on chromosome 7
Mutation of DNAI1 gene on chromosome 9
Deletion of UBE3A gene on chromosome 15

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Deletion of the codon for phenylalanine 508 in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 is the most common underlying cause of cystic fibrosis. This deletion leads to a misfolded CFTR protein that is unable to reach the cellular membrane. The CFTR protein is an important chloride channel in cell membranes, and when mutated cannot properly secrete intracellular chloride ions. This mutation causes exocrine glands to produce hyperviscous secretions that accumulate and damage different organs, mainly the lungs and pancreas.
Image Description:

A mutation in the CFTR gene results in defective protein synthesis and the absence of the ATP-gated chloride channel in the cell surface of epithelial cells throughout the body (intestinal and respiratory epithelia, sweat glands, exocrine pancreas, exocrine glands, and reproductive organs). Chloride and sodium are normally in equilibrium, but the accumulation of intracellular chloride due to the absence of a transporter results in the retention of intracellular sodium and water (due to osmosis). This ultimately results in hyperviscous mucus, which causes blockages of small organs and airways, inflammation, and end-organ damage.

B) INCORRECT:

Deficiency in adenosine deaminase leads to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Although patients with SCID can present with chronic diarrhea, recurrent infections, and failure to thrive as seen in this patient, chronic steatorrhea would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the DNAI1 gene on chromosome 9 is the underlying cause of primary ciliary dyskinesia, which can also manifest with recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and mucus plugs, as seen in this patient. However, a diagnosis of primary ciliary dyskinesia would not explain this patient's chronic steatorrhea and growth failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Deletion of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15 is associated with Angelman syndrome. Unlike this patient's presentation, Angelman syndrome typically manifests with intellectual disability, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent laughing (inappropriate laughter).

E) INCORRECT:

Deficiency in apolipoprotein B-48 leads to abetalipoproteinemia. While affected individuals can present with severe steatorrhea and failure to thrive as seen in this patient, recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and mucus plugs would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) results from a mutation that impairs the secretion of alpha-1 antitrypsin by hepatocytes. The lack of secretion leads to unchecked protease activity in the lungs and, consequently, the destruction of the pulmonary architecture, which can present with recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and failure to thrive as seen in this patient. However, AATD classically causes panacinar emphysema, which this patient does not have. Moreover, this patient lacks features of hepatitis and liver cirrhosis (secondary to intracellular accumulation of alpha-1 antitrypsin), such as abdominal distension from hepatosplenomegaly or ascites.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of failure to thrive, recurrent respiratory infections, and chronic steatorrhea should raise concern for cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he is easily fatigued and has not gained weight. He eats 3 meals and has 3 to 4 bowel movements daily with bulky stools that float. He had recurrent episodes of sinusitis in infancy. He is at the 15th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. A few scattered expiratory crackles are heard in the thorax. There is abdominal distention. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's failure to thrive?

choices.text: Tropheryma whipplei infiltration of intestinal villi
Mucosal damage from excessive gastric acid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small intestine bacterial overgrowth may present with diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and malabsorption. However, it is most commonly caused by complications of abdominal surgery (such as blind loop syndrome) and gastrointestinal motility disorders. Also, small intestine bacterial overgrowth would not explain this patient's recurrent upper respiratory infections.

B) INCORRECT:

T. whipplei infiltration of intestinal villi causes Whipple disease, which may present with malabsorption and steatorrhea. However, Whipple disease is rare and mainly affects men aged 48–54 years. In addition, most cases of Whipple disease are associated with enteropathic arthritis (classically preceding gastrointestinal symptoms) and may also be associated with sacroiliitis, fever, or polyserositis. Furthermore, recurrent episodes of sinusitis are suggestive of another diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency arising from hyperviscous pancreatic secretions in cystic fibrosis (CF) causes failure to thrive due to malabsorption. Additionally, patients often have abdominal distention (from bacterial fermentation of undigested food), steatorrhea, and deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). Over half of patients with CF will later develop exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

Diagnosis of CF is usually established during neonatal screening, as all newborns in the US are screened for CF. In this patient, CF can be confirmed with sweat chloride testing (gold standard) or DNA testing. A decreased stool chymotrypsin and pancreatic elastase are helpful in the diagnosis of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired intestinal amino acid transport is seen in Hartnup disease. While niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency from reduced tryptophan can cause diarrhea (from pellagra), these symptoms are usually associated with dermatitis, as well as neurologic symptoms (ataxia, confusion, dementia), which this patient lacks. Also, Hartnup disease would not explain the recurrent episodes of upper respiratory infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Mucosal damage from excessive gastric acid occurs in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which may present with steatorrhea and weight loss (due to inactivation of pancreatic enzymes from excess acid). However, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is usually associated with abdominal pain and recurrent, therapy-resistant peptic ulcer disease. In addition, the age of onset for Zollinger-Ellison is typically 30–50 years, and this diagnosis would not explain the recurrent upper respiratory infections seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Intestinal inflammatory reaction to gluten is seen in celiac disease. Celiac disease may present with malabsorption symptoms, such as steatorrhea, anemia, and failure to thrive, but it would not explain this patient's recurrent upper respiratory symptoms. Also, celiac disease often occurs in association with extraintestinal features including dermatological symptoms (e.g., dermatitis herpetiformis, vitiligo) and endocrine symptoms (e.g., autoimmune thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus).
questions.hint: This patient's presents with steatorrhea, abdominal distention, failure to thrive, and signs of anemia (fatigue, pale conjunctivae), all of which indicate malabsorption. Together with recurrent episodes of upper respiratory infections, this suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 2720-g (6-lb) female newborn delivered at 35 weeks’ gestation starts vomiting and becomes inconsolable 48 hours after birth. The newborn has not passed her first stool yet. Examination shows abdominal distention and high-pitched bowel sounds. A water-soluble contrast enema study shows microcolon. Serum studies show increased levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen. Which of the following is the most likely additional laboratory finding?

choices.text: Decreased hydrogen ion concentration in renal collecting duct
Increased chloride concentration in alveolar fluid
Increased bicarbonate concentration in pancreatic secretions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased hydrogen ion concentration in the renal collecting duct would not be expected in this patient. As a result of this neonate's vomiting, she is most likely hypovolemic with a contraction alkalosis. In cases of contraction alkalosis, aldosterone acts on the distal tubule to increase secretion of hydrogen and potassium ions in exchange for increased reabsorption of sodium ions. Therefore, she would be expected to have an increased, not decreased hydrogen ion concentration. Cystic fibrosis itself does not affect renal electrolyte concentrations because the CFTR protein is not expressed in the kidneys.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased chloride concentration in alveolar fluid is not expected in cases of cystic fibrosis. Chloride concentration in the alveolar fluid is established through the action of CFTR channels, which actively transport chloride ions into the alveoli. A defect of the CFTR protein in cystic fibrosis impairs the transport of chloride ions into the alveoli and leads to a decrease (not an increase) in alveolar chloride concentration. As a result of the diminished chloride transport, water molecules are not secreted and the resulting mucus is hyperviscous, leading to mucus plug formation.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased serum calcium concentration is not expected in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with (advanced) cystic fibrosis often present with signs and symptoms of malabsorption, including impaired absorption of vitamin D. Because vitamin D is essential for renal and intestinal reabsorption of calcium, vitamin D deficiency results in decreased serum calcium concentrations. In this neonate, serum calcium concentrations are most likely within the reference range.

D) INCORRECT:

An increase in bicarbonate concentration in pancreatic secretions occurs as a normal response to food intake; it would not be expected in cystic fibrosis. The defective CFTR protein in cystic fibrosis impairs the secretion of chloride, sodium, and bicarbonate ions from the pancreas, decreasing the water content of pancreatic secretions. In newborns with cystic fibrosis, decreased water content of pancreatic secretions contributes to the development of recalcitrant meconium. As patients with this condition age, the hyperviscous pancreatic secretions lead to sclerosis of the pancreatic ducts and, ultimately, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

E) CORRECT:

Increased sodium concentration in sweat is a result of impaired chloride ion transport; chloride transport is mediated by the CFTR channel and the gene for this channel is mutated in cystic fibrosis. In the most common CFTR gene mutation, the membrane transporter misfolds, causing it to be retained in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. As a result, chloride is not properly reabsorbed and remains in the lumen of the apocrine sweat gland. Positively charged sodium ions are also pathologically trapped in sweat by the negatively charged chloride ions in order to balance the net electric charge, resulting in hypertonic sweat.

Levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT) are measured as part of neonatal screening for cystic fibrosis. Elevated levels of IRT in heel-prick blood indicate that it has not been converted to its active form (trypsin), as a result of impaired release of pancreatic enzymes.
Image Description:

Sweating is induced using pilocarpine and an electrical current, and collected using preweighed filter paper covered with plastic wrap (to prevent evaporation) for up to 30 minutes. The concentration of chloride is measured and compared to reference ranges. A chloride concentration of ≥ 60 mmol/L reflects a likely diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.
questions.hint: This newborn's inability to pass her first stool (most likely caused by meconium ileus) and increased serum immunoreactive trypsinogen are indicative of cystic fibrosis as the underlying disease.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy who recently emigrated from Ukraine is brought to the physician for the evaluation of failure to thrive. Genetic analysis shows the deletion of the 508th codon in a gene on chromosome 7. The deletion results in defective post-translational folding of a protein and retention of the misfolded protein in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. The activity of which of the following channels is most likely to be increased as a result of the defect?

choices.text: Calcium release channels of the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Bicarbonate channels of pancreatic ductal cells
Sodium channels of respiratory epithelial cells
Chloride channels of epithelial cells in sweat glands
ATP-sensitive potassium channels of pancreatic beta cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium release channels of the sarcoplasmic reticulum are known as ryanodine receptors. Mutations of the genes encoding these channels are associated with increased activity of the ryanodine receptors, which predisposes individuals to malignant hyperthermia. The ryanodine receptor gene variants are located on chromosomes 1, 15, and 19, not on chromosome 7.

B) INCORRECT:

Bicarbonate channels of pancreatic ductal cells serve as Cl-/HCO3- exchangers, in which extracellular Cl- are exchanged for intracellular HCO3-. CFTR Cl- channels establish a high extracellular Cl- concentration, which allows for the exchange of HCO3- into the pancreatic juice. In cystic fibrosis, the defective Cl- channels lead to diminished activity of the HCO3- channels that rely on the Cl- gradient.

C) CORRECT:

Sodium channels of respiratory epithelial cells reabsorb Na+ from lung secretions to maintain an electrochemical equilibrium across cell membranes. The failure of ATP-gated Cl- channels (encoded by CFTR) to function leads to a decrease in Cl- in lung secretions. This, in turn, results in an increase in the activity of Na+ channels, which reabsorb Na+ ions into cells until an extremely positive gradient is created. These ion changes stimulate passive reabsorption of water from bronchial mucous into the cells and interstitium, resulting in abnormally thick bronchial secretions.

Reabsorption of Na+ results in a nasal transepithelial potential difference that is more negative than normal. This increased difference in electrical potential is helpful in diagnosing cystic fibrosis.
Image Description:

A mutation in the CFTR gene results in defective protein synthesis and the absence of the ATP-gated chloride channel in the cell surface of epithelial cells throughout the body (intestinal and respiratory epithelia, sweat glands, exocrine pancreas, exocrine glands, and reproductive organs). Chloride and sodium are normally in equilibrium, but the accumulation of intracellular chloride due to the absence of a transporter results in the retention of intracellular sodium and water (due to osmosis). This ultimately results in hyperviscous mucus, which causes blockages of small organs and airways, inflammation, and end-organ damage.

D) INCORRECT:

Cl- channels of epithelial cells in sweat glands first reabsorb Cl- from sweat, a process that is followed by Na+ and water reabsorption. Cl- channels are encoded by the CFTR gene, and defects lead to a decrease in activity of these channels. As a result, NaCl concentrations in sweat increase.

E) INCORRECT:

ATP-sensitive K+ channels of pancreatic beta cells are open when intracellular ATP concentrations are below a certain threshold, allowing K+ to flow into the cell. Glucose entry into the cells increases the intracellular ATP concentration, which arrests the flow of K+ and depolarizes the membrane, initiating insulin release. Defects of the gene encoding ATP-sensitive K+ channels result in hypoinsulinemia, which results in neonatal diabetes mellitus and failure to thrive. However, the gene is located on chromosome 11, not 7.
questions.hint: Deletion of the 508th codon, which encodes phenylalanine on the CFTR gene, is the most common mutation associated with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because of difficulty conceiving during the past year. He emigrated from rural Romania 2 years ago and has a history of recurrent respiratory infections since childhood for which he has not sought treatment. Physical examination shows mild hepatomegaly and clubbing of the nail beds. Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels are increased. Microscopic analysis of centrifuged seminal fluid shows no sperm cells. This patient's condition is most likely caused by impaired function of a channel protein that normally opens in response to binding of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetylcholine is a ligand that activates nicotinic receptors, which are nonselective channels for Na+ and K+. Damage to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors is implicated in the pathogenesis of myasthenia gravis, which would manifest with features such as diplopia, ptosis, and muscle weakness, not recurrent respiratory infections and infertility.

B) CORRECT:

The features of recurrent respiratory tract infections, hepatic dysfunction (due to hepatosteatosis), and azoospermia (due to vas deferens obstruction or congenital absence of vas deferens) are consistent with cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis is caused by a defect in the CFTR gene, which normally codes for a Cl- ion channel that is activated by the binding of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This ATP-gated Cl- channel secretes Cl- in the lungs and GI tract and reabsorbs Cl- in sweat glands.

The K+ channels on the pancreatic beta cells are another example of ion channels for which ATP is a ligand. Unlike the CFTR Cl- channels, however, these K+ channels are inhibited rather than activated by ATP.

C) INCORRECT:

A defect in dynein leads to Kartagener syndrome, which can cause recurrent respiratory tract infections, clubbing, and infertility. However, dynein is not a ligand that binds to an ion channel. Rather, it is a protein involved in the conversion of biochemical energy to mechanical energy. Moreover, semen analysis in patients with Kartagener syndrome would typically show sperm cells with immotility or uncoordinated motility; azoospermia is unusual in Kartagener syndrome, and hepatomegaly would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is a ligand that activates GABA-A receptors, which are Cl- channels present on neuronal membranes. Increased activity of these receptors hyperpolarizes neurons. This increased activity is also the underlying mechanism of benzodiazepines and barbiturates. This man's condition is caused by a defect in Cl- channels present in the lung, GI tract, and sweat glands, but GABA is not a ligand for these Cl- channels.

E) INCORRECT:

N-methyl-D-aspartate is a ligand that activates NMDA receptors, which are channels for positively charged ions such as Ca2+ and Na+. These receptors are present on neuronal membranes. Increased activity of NMDA receptors has been implicated in neurotoxicity in individuals with certain neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Huntington disease), but it would not explain this patient's clinical features.

F) INCORRECT:

Cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) increases the activity of the intestinal CFTR chloride channel, which is the channel protein impaired in this patient. This nucleotide indirectly increases the activity of this channel by activating a cGMP-dependent protein kinase without directly binding to it. cGMP also relaxes vascular smooth muscle, which is necessary for achieving an erection, by activating myosin-light-chain phosphatase. In addition, cGMP acts as a ligand for cyclic nucleotide-gated ion channels, which have been shown to activate post-ejaculatory capacitation reactions (spermatozoal maturation). This patient's infertility, however, is caused by the absence of spermatozoa in semen rather than by erectile dysfunction or a defect in sperm maturation.
questions.hint: This patient would have a positive sweat chloride test.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 5-hour history of right lower quadrant pain, vomiting, and abdominal distention. Examination shows a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated ascending colon with an air-fluid level in the small intestine. A test is performed in which electrodes are placed on the nasal epithelium and the nose is perfused with several different solutions. When a chloride-free solution is administered, hyperpolarization across the nasal epithelium is absent. Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in patients with the condition described here?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The liver is often affected in cystic fibrosis, with manifestations including cholestasis, hepatic steatosis, portal hypertension, and liver cirrhosis. However, liver cirrhosis is not a common cause of death in this patient group.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with cystic fibrosis are at a higher risk of developing pulmonary embolism compared to the general population, but it is not a common cause of death in this patient group.

C) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic tissue involvement is common in cystic fibrosis. Progressive destruction of pancreatic beta cells can result in a significant proportion of adult patients manifesting with diabetes mellitus. However, diabetes mellitus is not a common cause of death in patients with cystic fibrosis.

D) CORRECT:

The nasal potential difference test conducted here confirms the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in this patient. Patients with cystic fibrosis have hyperviscous exocrine gland secretions, which can thicken stool and cause distal intestinal obstruction, as seen here. Hyperviscous respiratory secretions and deficient mucociliary clearance lead to recurrent pulmonary infections. This, combined with multiple episodes of antibiotic therapy, leads to the development of more severe, resistant infections (e.g., Pseudomonas aeruginosa) and structural lung changes (e.g., bronchiectasis, emphysema), with eventual progression to respiratory failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Nephrolithiasis is more common in patients with cystic fibrosis than in the general population, and chronic nephrolithiasis can lead to renal failure and/or urosepsis. However, it is not a common cause of death in this patient group.
questions.hint: This patient has clinical findings consistent with distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (abdominal distention, RLQ pain, and a RLQ mass), most likely due to abnormal chloride transmembrane transport.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man with a history of recurrent sinus infections presents for evaluation. He says he has been hospitalized for pneumonia twice in the past year, one time requiring intravenous antibiotics for Pseudomonas aeruginosa. He was healthy as a child, except for occasional asthma attacks. Despite normal erectile function, he and his wife have had difficulty conceiving children for several years.
The patient reports some improvement in symptoms but still has a daily productive cough, severe exercise limitation, and dyspnea. Examination reveals normal vital signs, bilateral rhonchi in the mid zones, and scattered rales without wheezing.
A chest radiograph reveals no focal consolidations and possible, nonspecific airway thickening.
Which one of the following evaluations should this patient undergo next?

choices.text: Testosterone and serum luteinizing hormone testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin E testing (to diagnose allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis) and HIV testing are appropriate for a general workup of bronchiectasis. Testosterone and luteinizing hormone levels may be appropriate for a workup of male infertility. Galactomannan testing is appropriate serologic evaluation for suspected aspergillus infection. However, none of these tests would identify a cause of this patient’s entire clinical syndrome.

Immunoglobulin E testing (to diagnose allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis) and HIV testing are appropriate for a general workup of bronchiectasis. Testosterone and luteinizing hormone levels may be appropriate for a workup of male infertility. Galactomannan testing is appropriate serologic evaluation for suspected aspergillus infection. However, none of these tests would identify a cause of this patient’s entire clinical syndrome.

Immunoglobulin E testing (to diagnose allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis) and HIV testing are appropriate for a general workup of bronchiectasis. Testosterone and luteinizing hormone levels may be appropriate for a workup of male infertility. Galactomannan testing is appropriate serologic evaluation for suspected aspergillus infection. However, none of these tests would identify a cause of this patient’s entire clinical syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Bronchiectasis in young adults is frequently caused by cystic fibrosis (CF). Adult CF often manifests as mild but chronic sinopulmonary infections. Men with CF are often infertile due to congenital absence of the vas deferens. Diagnosis requires presentation with the appropriate clinical syndrome and either documentation of a sweat chloride level ≥ 60 mEq/liter on two occasions or identification of two CF transport regulator gene mutations.

Key learning point: The first diagnosis to consider in an adult male patient with bronchiectasis, recurrent sinopulmonary infections, and infertility is cystic fibrosis.
