However, none of these tests would identify a cause of this patient’s entire clinical syndrome.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman with a history of cystic fibrosis presents to the emergency department with increasing dyspnea associated with worsening cough and sputum production over the course of one week. She denies recent sick contacts. She reports adherence to airway-clearance techniques, including use of a chest physiotherapy vest, dornase alfa, and hypertonic saline 7%. The patient has also been taking inhaled tobramycin therapy (alternating on and off each month) for chronic infection with mucoid-type Pseudomonas aeruginosa. She reports having experienced a mild increase in sinus symptoms before her pulmonary symptoms worsened.
On examination, the patient has a temperature of 38.0°C, a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 105/67 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 90% while she is breathing ambient air. Physical examination reveals upper- and middle-zone crackles and rhonchi, but no other remarkable findings.
Laboratory results show a leukocyte count of 12,400 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with a differential of 90% neutrophils (40–70). A sputum culture reveals mucoid-type P. aeruginosa, similar to the outpatient sputum results.
Bedside spirometry reveals an FEV1 of 65% of predicted (baseline FEV1 was 77% of predicted).
A posterior-anterior/lateral chest radiograph shows predominantly upper-lobe bronchiectasis with acute focal opacities in the middle lobe.
Which one of the following treatment plans is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Delay initiation of antibiotic therapy until synergy antibiotic testing data are available
Begin intravenous tobramycin, ceftazidime, and vancomycin
Begin intravenous ceftazidime and continue inhaled tobramycin therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Single-drug intravenous antibiotic coverage is inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Although multidrug resistance is common in CF pathogens, awaiting antibiotic synergy testing to identify the appropriate antibiotic choice is an inferior strategy, compared with immediate empiric double coverage.

C) CORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is characterized by bronchiectasis that is due to chronic airway-centric inflammation and infection (most commonly with gram-negative organisms, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa) secondary to thick mucus.

The natural history of CF involves periods of worsening burden of infection and inflammation, leading to increased pulmonary symptoms and decline of baseline spirometry (i.e., acute pulmonary exacerbations). These severe exacerbations are routinely treated with (1) a combination of two intravenous antipseudomonal antibiotics, according to prior therapeutic response; and (2) increased frequency, above the home regimen, of airway-clearance methods, including chest physiotherapy and mucolytic therapies (hypertonic saline and dornase alfa).

Key learning point: Appropriate management for a patient with an acute pulmonary exacerbation of cystic fibrosis and a sputum culture positive for Pseudomonas aeruginosa consists of a combination of two intravenous antipseudomonal antibiotics, plus increased intensity of airway-clearance methods

D) INCORRECT:

Addition of an antistaphylococcal drug such as vancomycin is inappropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Single-drug intravenous antibiotic coverage and failure to escalate antibiotic coverage beyond inhaled tobramycin are inappropriate.

questions.text:
During the past year, a 25-year-old man has had two episodes of radiographically confirmed lobar pneumonia, both treated successfully with oral antibiotics, and one episode of otitis media. Two years ago, he had anemia that was treated with glucocorticoids.
At his visit today, he has a BMI of 23, a blood pressure of 112/72 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and a normal lung examination.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic granulomatous disease involves a primary neutrophil function defect, and patients usually present with recurrent, catalase-positive, life-threatening bacterial infections during the first 5 years of life.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients who have cystic fibrosis typically present with recurrent respiratory illnesses and growth failure during early childhood.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a primary T-cell defect that can affect B cells and natural killer cells; symptoms start in the first 6 months of life.

D) CORRECT:

Common variable immunodeficiency results primarily from a sporadic mutation (as seen in 90% of patients) rather than a familial pattern of inheritance (10% of patients). Age of onset is typically between 20 and 40 years. In contrast, the other immunodeficiencies listed are inherited and tend to manifest earlier in life. Common variable immunodeficiency is associated with diminished humoral function, which results in recurrent infections and autoimmune cytopenias (such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia).

Key learning point: In addition to manifesting with noninfectious granulomatous disease, common variable immunodeficiency can manifest with autoimmune cytopenias (such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and recurrent sinopulmonary infections.

E) INCORRECT:

X-linked agammaglobulinemia, which involves a defect of B-cell development, manifests with recurrent sinopulmonary infections during the first 2 years of life.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 25-year-old woman reports frequent infections during the past 3 years, including several sinus infections and two episodes of pneumonia.
A purified protein derivative test, sputum testing for acid-fast bacilli, and HIV serology testing are all negative. A chest radiograph is within normal limits.
Other laboratory testing reveals a normal leukocyte count, and flow cytometry documents normal B-cell and T-cell counts. Immunoglobulin (Ig) G and A levels are low; IgM and IgE levels are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Common variable immune deficiency (CVID) is a disease of immune dysfunction. Key features include hypogammaglobulinemia, deficient specific antibody responses, and increased risk for autoimmune disorders such as immune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune neutropenia. B-cell and T-cell counts may be normal or low in patients with CVID. Clinical manifestations of CVID include frequent upper and lower respiratory tract infections, as well as recurrent gastrointestinal infections in some cases.

Key learning point: The immunodeficiency disorder that is most likely to be associated with recurrent sinus and respiratory infections in a young adult is common variable immune deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Adult-onset cystic fibrosis or alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency could cause chronic relapsing lung symptoms, but not low immunoglobulin levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic granulomatous disease can cause sinusitis and pneumonia, but it generally manifests in the first two years of life and is also accompanied by abscess formation.

D) INCORRECT:

Complement factor 2 deficiency typically manifests with sepsis rather than recurrent sinus and lung infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Adult-onset cystic fibrosis could cause chronic relapsing lung symptoms, but not low immunoglobulin levels.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman with cystic fibrosis (CF) presents for evaluation of a productive cough that has been worsening for 2 weeks despite a course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She has had one week of intermittent low-grade fevers to a maximum of 38.1°C. During the past year, her FEV1 has been stable at 86% of the predicted value. Her most recent hospitalization was 18 months ago for a pulmonary exacerbation.
She is thin with a BMI of 19. Her temperature is 37.9°C, her heart rate is 101 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 113/84 mm Hg. She has a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, with mild subcostal and suprasternal retractions, and an oxygen saturation of 94% while breathing ambient air. Auscultation reveals fine crackles on inspiration. Her FEV1 is 79% of the predicted value for her age.
Which one the following pathogens is most likely to be contributing to her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

During infancy and early childhood, Staphylococcus aureus and Haemophilus influenzae are the primary colonizers of the lungs in patients with CF.

B) INCORRECT:

During adolescence and early adulthood, colonization and infection by Pseudomonas aeruginosa start to rise. Although colonization with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) also increases in early adulthood, MRSA is a less common organism than P. aeruginosa at all ages. Vancomycin and linezolid are often used if the patient has a known history of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infection or colonization.

C) CORRECT:

Decline in pulmonary function is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). The hallmark of pulmonary disease in CF is recurrent, progressive inflammation and infection. Delayed mucociliary clearance creates an ideal environment for microbial growth in the lungs of patients with CF. As a result, the pulmonary microbiome of affected patients is highly diverse, and the prevalence of distinct pathogenic organisms evolves as the patient grows older. It is important to be familiar with the pathogens most likely to be present in a patient with CF and to review past cultures to help guide empiric antibiotic therapy.

For young adults with CF, empiric treatment for an acute pulmonary exacerbation generally includes a beta-lactam, to cover Pseudomonas species, as well as an aminoglycoside (two agents are used to reduce the development of resistant strains). Vancomycin and linezolid are often used if the patient has a known history of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infection or colonization.

Key learning point: In a young adult with cystic fibrosis, one of the most common pathogenic organisms linked with pulmonary symptoms is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinomyces species are frequently isolated from CF patients of all ages. In some reports, Actinomyces and other anaerobes constituted nearly half of the microbial community in the sputum of CF patients. However, the role of Actinomyces in CF lung disease is uncertain.

E) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus that may colonize the lungs of up to 20% of patients with CF. However, its role in the development of pulmonary complications is unclear.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought in by her parents for evaluation of a long-standing wet cough (since age 6 months) and a fever that developed 2 days ago (maximum recorded temperature, 39.0°C).
On examination, she has a temperature of 38.7°C, a respiratory rate of 41 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 140 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. Her weight and height have been stable at the 75th percentile. On lung examination, she has prominent focal crackles in the right middle lung field and a few scattered crackles in other lung fields, but no retractions. Her heart sounds, heart rhythm, and distal pulses are all normal. Her abdomen is soft and nontender, and there is no hepatosplenomegaly. Her extremities are well perfused, and she has normal capillary refill.
Her parents report that her chronic wet cough is neither seasonal nor aggravated by any particular trigger. She has tried albuterol without relief. She has had four bacterial pneumonias within the past 2 years. She has also required placement of tympanostomy tubes because of recurrent ear infections. She has never wheezed or had coughing or choking episodes associated with eating. Her newborn screening was normal. Previous chest radiographs show that her heart is a normal size and shape and that the prior pneumonias were in various lung fields.
Covid-19 is ruled out, antibiotics are prescribed for community-acquired pneumonia, and further testing is arranged.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s recurrent symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although upper and lower respiratory tract infections are common in young children, this patient has had a significant number of bacterial respiratory infections requiring antibiotics and should undergo evaluation for conditions that predispose to such infections.

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare, autosomal recessive condition that manifests early in life with chronic cough, pneumonias, and chronic ear infections. Because the symptoms are so similar to those of other childhood illnesses, PCD is often not diagnosed until late childhood or even adulthood. Diagnosis can be challenging. It is based on history, physical examination, and a combination of a nasal ciliary biopsy, electron microscopy, a low nasal nitric oxide level, and genetic testing.

Key learning point: The combination of chronic respiratory infections, a chronic wet cough, and frequent ear infections in a child with normal weight gain and a normal newborn screen should raise suspicion for primary ciliary dyskinesia.

B) INCORRECT:

Asthma can lead to inflammation and mucosal edema in the lower airways. This in turn leads to mucus retention and can be the reason for recurrent pneumonia in children. However, asthma is unlikely in this patient, given that she did not respond to albuterol.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune deficiencies, specifically common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), often manifest with recurrent bacterial infections, including respiratory infections. Patients with an immune deficiency usually have poor growth and recurrent bacterial infections in multiple organ systems. This patient’s history is more consistent with a disease that primarily affects the respiratory tract.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic aspiration is unlikely in a neurologically normal child with no reported history of choking or gagging. Furthermore, it would not explain this patient’s recurrent otitis media.

E) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is one of the most common genetic conditions that affects the airways. Newborns are screened for CF in all 50 states, but the test is not 100% sensitive. Individuals who present with CF after infancy often have a combination of recurrent bacterial respiratory infections (pulmonary, sinus, or both), poor weight gain and growth, and gastrointestinal symptoms (either diarrhea or constipation). A sweat test is indicated for this patient, but CF is not the most likely diagnosis, given her negative newborn screen and normal growth parameters.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl reports that she has had recurrent pulmonary, ear, and sinus infections for as long as she can remember. She had tympanostomy tubes placed when she was 3 years of age and has undergone multiple sinus surgeries, the last being one year ago. She recently had a chest radiograph that showed a left-sided infiltrate and was prescribed 5 days of azithromycin. She is being seen in the office today because she has not improved.
Physical examination reveals crackles and rhonchi throughout the left side of her chest.
CT of the chest is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis can manifest with bronchiectasis and sinopulmonary disease, but it is not associated with situs inversus.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic aspiration, chronic granulomatous disease, and common variable immunodeficiency are not associated with situs inversus.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic aspiration, chronic granulomatous disease, and common variable immunodeficiency are not associated with situs inversus.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic aspiration, chronic granulomatous disease, and common variable immunodeficiency are not associated with situs inversus.

E) CORRECT:

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare, autosomal recessive, heterogeneous group of disorders affecting the structure of the cilia; it manifests in childhood. The cilia beat more slowly than normal or beat with an abnormal pattern, impairing mucociliary clearance and causing chronic airways disease.

The main complications of PCD involve the upper respiratory tract (sinus infections, chronic otitis media with effusion, or hearing loss), lower respiratory tract (bronchiectasis), cardiovascular system (situs inversus), and reproductive system (infertility, subfertility, or recurrent ectopic pregnancies). About 50% of patients with PCD have Kartagener’s syndrome, which is characterized by the triad of sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (as shown in this patient’s CT scan).

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with bronchiectasis, recurrent sinus and ear infections, and situs inversus is primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis (CF) presents for follow-up care. She has generally been doing well, is physically active, and is an excellent student. She reports no dyspnea, chest pain, increased sputum, abdominal pain, watery stool, or pruritus. She is gaining weight appropriately, along the 50th percentile for her age. She reports continued adherence to her airway-clearance and pancreatic-enzyme therapies.
Today, for the first time, a liver edge is appreciated 1 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory testing reveals a normal complete blood count with differential, a normal international normalized ratio, and mild elevations in both alanine aminotransferase (50 U/liter; reference range, 10–30) and aspartate aminotransferase (55 U/liter; 13–35). GGT, alkaline phosphatase, and total bilirubin levels are all normal.
A complete abdominal ultrasound with Doppler shows no evidence of portal hypertension or liver disease.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient’s evaluation?

choices.text: Order laboratory testing for viral infections, including hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and Epstein-Barr virus
Repeat measurement of liver aminotransferase and gamma-glutamyltransferase levels in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Liver test abnormalities can result from hepatotropic viral infections. However, this patient has no signs of infection (e.g., fever or lymphadenopathy) and thus no indication for viral testing at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Ursodeoxycholic acid, an oral medication that increases bile flow, may prevent or delay progression of CF-related liver disease, but current data are insufficient to justify routine use in patients without clear evidence of such disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Transient elastography scans measure liver stiffness (fibrosis) noninvasively and are currently used to stage patients with chronic liver disease. The value of elastography in the setting of CF is currently being explored; there are no guidelines yet for its use.

D) CORRECT:

Liver disease is a complication of cystic fibrosis (CF), affecting 27% to 35% of patients with CF. Affected patients are often asymptomatic, even in the setting of cirrhosis. Thus, an annual assessment for hepatic dysfunction with physical examination and laboratory testing is recommended for all children with CF.

This patient’s annual assessment revealed a liver edge palpable 1 cm below the costal margin and mild elevations in aminotransferase levels. The liver edge is within normal range (hepatomegaly would be a concern if the liver was palpable >2 cm below the costal margin or if a prominent left lobe was palpable in the epigastrium), but the elevation in aminotransferase levels required further evaluation with ultrasound. Those results were reassuring, and the patient can now return to routine follow-up.

Liver Disease in CF

Liver involvement in CF includes a wide spectrum of diseases ranging from transient elevations in liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase [ALT], aspartate aminotransferase [AST], gamma-glutamyltransferase [GGT], and alkaline phosphatase) to mild steatosis to portal hypertension, multilobular cirrhosis, and liver failure necessitating liver transplantation. The majority of severe complications from CF-related liver disease occur in children in the first decade of life; incidence then declines sharply in the second decade.

There is evidence that liver disease in patents with CF results from sludge in the biliary tract, secondary to impaired chloride secretion from a defective CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), with resultant obstruction and retention of toxins, which then leads to peribiliary fibrosis, hepatocyte damage, and focal biliary cirrhosis. In addition, a combination of chronic infections, medications, and translocation of bacteria to the portal circulation from an impaired intestinal epithelial barrier has been proposed to contribute to liver disease.

Screening for Liver Disease in CF

An annual physical examination with laboratory testing can detect early signs of CF-related liver disease, before changes become pronounced. The most common physical finding is hepatomegaly with a firm and nodular enlargement; other signs include splenomegaly, spider nevi, jaundice, ascites, and distention of abdominal wall veins. Laboratory testing reveals mild elevations in aminotransferase levels in an estimated 40% to 50% of patients with CF. Elevations in AST, ALT, and GGT therefore have a low sensitivity and specificity for liver pathology.

Patients who have physical signs of liver disease or abnormal liver function tests at their annual visit should be referred for complete abdominal ultrasound with Doppler.

• If the ultrasound suggests liver disease, portal hypertension, or both, a liver biopsy and endoscopy should be performed to assess for varices.
• If the liver-enzyme or GGT levels are no more than two times the upper limit of normal (ULN) and the ultrasound is normal or shows only mild steatosis, the next step is to repeat the liver-enzyme studies in 6 to 12 months.
• If the liver-enzyme or GGT levels are more than two times the ULN or remain elevated for >6 months, the clinician should investigate for other possible causes of liver disease, such as excessive alcohol use, infectious hepatitis, drug-induced liver disease, Wilson disease, autoimmune hepatitis, alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency, and celiac disease.

In this case, the patient has no presenting complaints, a normal physical examination, only a modest increase in aminotransferase levels, and a reassuring ultrasound; she therefore requires only routine follow-up.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in evaluation for an adolescent with cystic fibrosis who has a modest elevation in aminotransferase levels and no evidence of liver disease on ultrasound is repeat laboratory testing in 6 months.

E) INCORRECT:

Liver biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing liver disease. Signs of liver disease or portal hypertension on ultrasound, such as increased heterogeneity, echogenicity, irregular margins, nodularity, reversal of portal blood flow, large collateral veins or ascites, would be indications for a liver biopsy. In the absence of discrete lesions on ultrasound or other concerning clinical features, the yield of a liver biopsy is likely to be low and must be balanced against the risks associated with the procedure.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy with cystic fibrosis (CF) presents to the emergency department reporting persistent, worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past 8 weeks, as well as acute-onset vomiting for one day.
His CF has been complicated by pancreatic insufficiency, poor weight gain, and CF-related diabetes requiring insulin. To attain adequate nutrition for catch-up, he eats three full meals and three snacks daily. His pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy consists of 10,000 units of lipase/kg/meal and 5000 units of lipase/kg/snack. Three weeks ago, he completed a course of cefazolin for a respiratory flare of his lung disease; it was his second flare requiring intravenous antibiotics in the past 3 months.
His medical history is also notable for acute appendicitis requiring appendectomy at 6 years of age, gastroesophageal reflux disease requiring omeprazole 40 mg daily for the past 6 months, and constipation requiring senna 15 mg daily for the past 6 years.
On examination, the patient appears ill. He weighs 31 kg, measures 144 cm, and has a BMI of 14.9. He is afebrile, tachycardic, and normotensive. He has tenderness in the right lower quadrant and guarding but no rebound. Bowel sounds are diminished, and there is mild abdominal distention.
An abdominal CT scan reveals thickening of the ascending colon wall with narrowing of the intestinal lumen and loss of colonic haustra. Mild ascites is apparent with no intestinal air-fluid levels.
Which one of the following components of care is most likely to have put this patient at risk for his current symptoms?

choices.text: Excessive dosage of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy
Prolonged use of a stimulant laxative

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) has been linked to recurrent gastrointestinal and respiratory infections, bone fractures, hypomagnesemia, and rebound acidity. However, no published reports have linked PPI use to fibrosing colonopathy.

questions.text:
A 6-week-old boy is brought in for a weight check because of growth concerns. He was born at 38 weeks and 3 days’ gestation via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery to a now gravida 1 para 1 healthy mother and a healthy father. The pregnancy course was uncomplicated.
On day 2 of life, the patient’s abdominal examination revealed a mildly distended but soft abdomen and a patent anus without abnormal positioning or size. An abdominal radiograph revealed mildly dilated loops of small bowel, and contrast enema radiography subsequently demonstrated a borderline small-caliber colon. The infant passed meconium soon after administration of the enema; he was then able to feed and pass bowel movements without difficulty and was discharged home.
During the past month, his parents report that he has been feeding vigorously without difficulty or emesis, is passing yellow seedy stools with each bowel movement, and is producing at least 7 wet diapers daily. He takes 90 mL of milk-based formula every 3 hours.
On examination, his weight is at the 3rd percentile (he was born at the 50th percentile). He appears well and vigorous, and his chest is clear. Abdominal examination reveals a soft, nondistended abdomen.
Results of the state newborn screen, including immunoreactive trypsinogen testing, were within the normal range.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

A contrast enema with barium will show a transition zone for most affected infants, but if the test is obtained too early in the neonatal period, the transition zone may not have had ample time to develop. The gold standard for diagnosis is a rectal suction biopsy looking for absence of ganglion cells.

Poor weight gain in an infant who is taking in adequate amounts of formula and has been passing stool regularly for several weeks without vomiting is not typical of Hirschsprung disease. This infant should therefore undergo evaluation for CF first (which also has the advantage of being noninvasive); if CF is ruled out, the clinician should remain alert to the possibility of Hirschsprung disease.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has no signs of obstruction to warrant a repeat abdominal radiograph. Similarly, he has no symptoms to suggest milk-protein sensitivity, such as blood in the stool or excessive irritability, so there is no indication to switch to an elemental formula.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has no signs of obstruction to warrant a repeat abdominal radiograph.

Repeat newborn screening is not indicated in this patient given that his clinical picture is worrisome for CF. In this scenario, a sweat test would be indicated regardless of whether the newborn screen was abnormal.

This patient’s presentation is concerning for simple meconium ileus with poor weight gain at 6 weeks of age despite adequate intake of a milk-based formula.

This thicker meconium may obstruct the terminal ileum or small intestines, leading to delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distention, and signs of small-bowel obstruction. For simple meconium ileus (i.e., evidence of meconium ileus without complication), the hyperosmolar contrast used in a contrast enema may itself be therapeutic, resulting in passage of the meconium.

All 50 U.S. states and many other countries now screen newborns for CF using an immunoreactive trypsinogen testing (IRT)-based assay, which measures the presence of a pancreatic enzyme precursor in heel-stick blood. Infants with a positive IRT screen then undergo second-tier testing for common CFTR mutations. Although the IRT-based assay is quite sensitive, it may yield false-negative results in rare cases. Thus, when clinical suspicion for CF is high, such as in cases of meconium ileus, sweat testing and consideration of CFTR genotyping is warranted.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic test for a 6-week-old boy with poor weight gain who is stooling normally, has a neonatal history concerning for meconium ileus, and had a negative state newborn screen is sweat testing.

• Year-round daily nasal congestion beginning before 6 months of age
• Organ laterality defect

This patient meets two of the four criteria and should be further evaluated for PCD. Currently, three tests are available for diagnosing this condition:

• Genetic testing
• Nasal nitric oxide (NO) levels, which can be measured only in specialized centers and are challenging to complete in children <5 years of age
• Transmission electron microscopy, which is less sensitive than an extended genetic testing panel

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office because of an increasing productive cough with a moderate amount of white phlegm for the past week. He has been treated for pneumonia with antibiotic therapy four times over the past year. He has had multiple episodes of foul-smelling, bulky, greasy stools. He is at the 3rd percentile for height and at the 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 44/min. A few inspiratory crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best initial test to determine the underlying etiology of this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) may be helpful in evaluating for restrictive or obstructive lung disease. However, PFTs would not be specific enough to determine the underlying etiology of this boy's illness. Also, PFTs may be difficult to obtain in children less than 6 years of age and therefore are not completely reliable.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum immunoglobulin levels may be low in immunodeficiency states like selective IgA deficiency (showing low IgA and normal IgG and IgM) or common variable immunodeficiency (showing low levels of IgA, IgG, and IgM). While both conditions can manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea, they are not commonly associated with steatorrhea and failure to thrive.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has typical clinical manifestations of cystic fibrosis (CF; chronic sinopulmonary disease, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency). The sweat chloride test, or quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis, is the gold standard test for CF. Defective chloride channels lead to elevated chloride in sweat gland secretions; levels > 60 mmol/L on two or more occasions are diagnostic for this condition.

Key learning point: The sweat chloride test is the gold standard initial diagnostic test for cystic fibrosis, detecting elevated chloride levels due to defective CFTR channels.

D) INCORRECT:

Stool analysis, particularly measurements of stool elastase or chymotrypsin, would be useful for diagnosing exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. However, this would not confirm the patient's underlying cause of pancreatic insufficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

DNA phenotyping may be performed for this patient's condition if there is high clinical suspicion and the best initial test is negative, or performed after best initial testing is positive to help guide treatment decisions. However, it would not be the best initial test (and is not used for screening), as it is expensive and results are not obtained quickly.
questions.hint: The underlying illness can manifest with meconium ileus in the neonatal period.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office because of increasing swelling of his legs and generalized fatigue for 1 month. During this period he has also had a productive cough and shortness of breath. He has a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections and chronic nasal congestion since childhood. He has a 3-month history of foul-smelling and greasy stools. He is at the 4th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows clubbing of his fingers and scoliosis. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Jugular venous distention is present. Inspiratory crackles are heard in the thorax. Cardiac examination shows a loud S2. The abdomen is mildly distended and the liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis in children can cause cardiac failure and is most commonly caused by a viral infection (e.g., coxsackie virus, adenovirus, parvovirus B19, EBV, CMV). So a history of a recent respiratory/gastrointestinal illness which precedes the onset of cardiac complaints is commonly present. However, this child has a history of chronic respiratory complaints and additional clinical features (steatorrhea, failure to thrive) that cannot be explained by myocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe protein malnutrition can result in dependent edema, failure to thrive, recurrent infections, and rarely, heart failure. However, pure protein malnutrition does not cause steatorrhea or clubbing. A child with protein malnutrition severe enough to cause heart failure would also have other significant clinical features, such as bradycardia (rather than tachycardia), dry, brittle hair and nails, dry skin, and redundant skin folds.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency can also present with respiratory complaints (chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and fatigue due to emphysema), failure to thrive, and cor pulmonale. However, features of liver disease (hepatitis or cirrhosis) would also be expected. Also, α1-antitrypsin deficiency does not cause steatorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with Goodpasture syndrome can present with respiratory complaints, such as dyspnea and chronic cough (due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage), and edema (due to the proteinuria of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). However, pancreatic involvement (as evidenced by steatorrhea) and systemic symptoms (fatigue and failure to thrive) are characteristically absent in patients with Goodpasture syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) present with multiorgan disease (especially of the lungs and the pancreas) due to hyperviscosity of exocrine secretions. This patient has a history of chronic respiratory tract disease (productive cough, recurrent respiratory tract infections, and chronic nasal congestion), which has caused cor pulmonale to develop and result in right heart failure (pedal edema, dyspnea, elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and a loud S2). His fatty stools are a sign of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Moreover, failure to thrive (< 5th percentile for height- and weight-for-age), clubbing, and scoliosis are typical in CF, making it the most likely diagnosis.

Although CF is mostly diagnosed within the first 2 weeks of life (either on routine screening/evaluation of a neonate with meconium ileus) or within the first 2 years of life (in children with recurrent respiratory tract infections and failure to thrive), some patients with CF may be missed on routine screening and present in later childhood, adolescence or early adulthood. The clinical diagnosis of CF should be confirmed by performing the sweat chloride test, abnormal nasal potential difference test, or gene studies for CFTR gene mutation.
questions.hint: This condition also commonly results in nephrolithiasis and cholelithiasis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman with cystic fibrosis (CF) presents for evaluation of a productive cough that has been worsening for 2 weeks despite a course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She has had one week of intermittent low-grade fevers to a maximum of 38.1°C. During the past year, her FEV1 has been stable at 86% of the predicted value. She has a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, with mild subcostal and suprasternal retractions, and an oxygen saturation of 94% while breathing ambient air. Auscultation reveals fine crackles on inspiration. Her FEV1 is 79% of the predicted value for her age. Which one the following pathogens is most likely to be contributing to her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

During infancy and early childhood, Staphylococcus aureus and Haemophilus influenzae are the primary colonizers of the lungs in patients with CF.

B) INCORRECT:

During adolescence and early adulthood, colonization and infection by Pseudomonas aeruginosa start to rise. Although colonization with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) also increases in early adulthood, MRSA is a less common organism than P. aeruginosa at all ages. Vancomycin and linezolid are often used if the patient has a known history of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infection or colonization.

C) CORRECT:

Decline in pulmonary function is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). The hallmark of pulmonary disease in CF is recurrent, progressive inflammation and infection. Delayed mucociliary clearance creates an ideal environment for microbial growth in the lungs of patients with CF. As a result, the pulmonary microbiome of affected patients is highly diverse, and the prevalence of distinct pathogenic organisms evolves as the patient grows older. For young adults with CF, empiric treatment for an acute pulmonary exacerbation generally includes a beta-lactam, to cover Pseudomonas species, as well as an aminoglycoside (two agents are used to reduce the development of resistant strains). Vancomycin and linezolid are often used if the patient has a known history of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infection or colonization.

Key learning point: In a young adult with cystic fibrosis, one of the most common pathogenic organisms linked with pulmonary symptoms is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinomyces species are frequently isolated from CF patients of all ages. In some reports, Actinomyces and other anaerobes constituted nearly half of the microbial community in the sputum of CF patients. However, the role of Actinomyces in CF lung disease is uncertain.

E) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus that may colonize the lungs of up to 20% of patients with CF. However, its role in the development of pulmonary complications is unclear.
